Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2007 11:12AM Candyce wrote: Bimmer, You said that so beautifully.  I am sure you are so right about being at home.  and the support you gave you darling Diane not only was comforting to her--I cannot help but think what a fine example you set for your children.  While you may not have been thinking of that part, it will affect them deeply. A dear friend of mine had a brain tumor and only lived 8 months after diagnosis.  Her newly married daughter in her brand new house moved her Mom, Dad and three younger sisters in with her and her new husband.  They made the living room into a beautiful room for her Mom and they would gather around her much of the time.  Teh youngest was only seven and she would sit on the bed and lay down with her Mom.  The father would have been hard pressed to do this on his own with having the younger children. He also took off from work for several months. Their fine example has meant so much to me.  And yours does too. I am so thankful there are people like you!
Posts.Title: Badboob67 sent me over the edge. Bimmer jansdaughter

Posts.Content: Candyce wrote: I am so upset with myself. Here I am a nurse and I just allowed two mantouz (TB) tests to be done on my affected arm. Not only the needle stick but the solution! I need something to remind myself of this precaution. A bracelet seems the answer. It would need to be fine and light as it is my right hand and I write alot. If it is the least bit uncomfortable I know I will take it off. Any ideas? Candyce Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: bracelet help needed Candyce Binney4

Posts.Content: Candyce wrote: My nodes were removed from right side. As I am right handed, of course, everything happens to that hand. I have burned, cut, scraped it many times. I clean it, put neopsorin on it and band aide if necessary. It has worked so far. Recently I was having a battle with a chicken (not a live one!) and got a small puncture wound from the tip of a knife in my right pinkie. Very small. I did my usual treatment. The next day it was painful and I thought I couldn't bend it because of the bandaide. When I was changing it I realized it was one and a half size of what it usually is--and was shiny. No drainage. I called primary right away (is that who one calls?) and she ordered Duracef. Is that the right treatment? It is still swollen today but is less read and less painful. I appreciate your advice on this. I was a wreck at work last evening and almost had my DH post for me. I know it is overreaction for one small pinky. Candyce Candyce Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Is this the right treatment? Candyce DoreenF

Posts.Content: Candyce wrote: I have had coccyx pain and recently had an xray.  It said arthritis.  What worries me is my Mom (years ago) had the same thing and the first xray said arthritis and the second bone mets.  Have any of you had that happen. Now I am very tender in my ribs just under mastectomy.  I am trying not to think about it but it isn't working. Candyce Candyce Log in to post a reply
